user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of named_thread_starter:
```c
static MHD_THRD_RTRN_TYPE_ MHD_THRD_CALL_SPEC_
named_thread_starter (void *data)
{
  struct MHD_named_helper_param_ *const param =
    (struct MHD_named_helper_param_ *) data;
  void *arg;
  MHD_THREAD_START_ROUTINE_ thr_func;

  if (NULL == data)
    return (MHD_THRD_RTRN_TYPE_) 0;

  MHD_set_cur_thread_name_ (param->name);

  arg = param->arg;
  thr_func = param->start_routine;
  free (data);

  return thr_func (arg);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function named_thread_starter:
struct MHD_named_helper_param_
{
  /**
   * Real thread start routine
   */
  MHD_THREAD_START_ROUTINE_ start_routine;

  /**
   * Argument for thread start routine
   */
  void *arg;

  /**
   * Name for thread
   */
  const char *name;
}
...
typedef MHD_THRD_RTRN_TYPE_
(MHD_THRD_CALL_SPEC_ *MHD_THREAD_START_ROUTINE_)(void *cls)
...
#define MHD_set_cur_thread_name_(n) MHD_set_thread_name_(pthread_self(),(n))
...
#define MHD_THRD_RTRN_TYPE_ void*
...
#define MHD_THRD_CALL_SPEC_ 
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No code fragment modifies the pointer parameter 'data' itself. The function only: (1) tests 'data' for NULL, (2) creates a local pointer 'param' initialized from 'data' (struct MHD_named_helper_param_ *const param = (struct ...) data; — this does not change 'data'), (3) reads members via 'param' (param->arg, param->start_routine, param->name), (4) calls free(data) which deallocates the object referred to by the pointer (the rule permits modifying the object pointed to by a pointer parameter), and (5) calls the start routine with the saved argument. There are no assignments to the parameter variable 'data' (no statements like data = ...), so the pointer itself is not modified. Therefore, under MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 this function does not present a violation and no fragments require further investigation.
